I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bangladesh requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 2006 
Country Program Confirmation Mission to provide assistance for skills development. A project 
preparatory technical assistance (TA) fact-finding mission visited Bangladesh from 26 to 31 
January  2006  to  review  the  rationale,  scope,  implementation  schedule  and  arrangements, 
financing plan, framework, and terms of reference for the TA. The mission met senior officials of 
the Ministry of Education (MOE); Directorate of Technical Education; Bangladesh Technical 
Education  Board;  Bureau  of  Manpower,  Employment  and  Training;  Economic  Relations 
Division;  Planning  Commission;  and  development  partners.  The  draft  memorandum  of 
understanding was discussed during a wrap-up meeting on 2 February 2006, chaired by the 
secretary of MOE. The memorandum of understanding presents the TA design and monitoring 
framework (Appendix 1) and reflects the discussions and understandings reached between the 
Government and ADB regarding its scope and arrangements.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Government’s National Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRS) paper prioritizes technical 
and  vocational  education  and  training  (TVET)  and  making  education  more  job-oriented  to 
accelerate poverty reduction. The PRS paper recognizes that the lack of skilled workers limits 
the growth of some sectors of the economy and that the lack of appropriate skills and education 
prevents the unskilled and the poor from earning.2 Among government goals is to “substantially 
increase the proportion of post-primary students enrolling in TVET.” TVET aims to increase the 
number of graduates working locally and abroad; increase the number of students passing 
terminal certificate examinations; and expand opportunities for the poor, youth, and women. 
 
3.  The TVET subsector offers both long- and short-term skills training. Government and 
nongovernment  training  providers,  including  madrasahs,  offer  long-term  TVET.  Over  160 
government schools and training institutions under MOE and the Ministry of Expatriate Welfare 
and  Overseas  Employment,  as  well  as  over  1,100  nongovernment  training  providers  offer 
certificate and diploma3 training programs. The vocational stream is available from grade 9. At 
least 40 trades, including dressmaking, fish culture and breeding, electrical maintenance, civil 
construction,  and  automotive  repair  and  maintenance,  are  offered.  Students  may  take  the 
secondary  school  certificate  (vocational—SSC[Voc])  examination  after  completing  the 
vocational stream curriculum in grade 10. Successful students can continue with the vocational 
stream at grades 11 and 12, leading to the higher secondary certificate (vocational—HSC[Voc]). 
Students can enroll in degree programs after passing the HSC(Voc) examination. Alternatively, 
SSC(Voc) certificate holders may enroll in polytechnic institutions, in programs leading to a 
technical education diploma. In 2002, over 140,000 students were enrolled in certificate and 
diploma TVET programs.  
 
4.  The ministries of youth and sports, and women’s and children’s affairs, as well as 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  offer  short-term  training.  These  are  mainly  for  self-
employment,  and  some  are  combined  with  microcredit  programs.  Some  training  providers 
conducting long-term training also offer short-term training. For-profit private trade schools offer 
short-term training programs, primarily in connection with foreign labor demand.

5.  The TVET system needs to make its training programs more relevant. Although skilled 
labor  is  lacking  in  various  sectors,  many  training  graduates  are  still  unemployed  or 
underemployed. The placement rates of public training providers are estimated to be from 40% 
and 65%.4 Training programs should address local and foreign labor market needs5 and should 
lead to jobs or income-generating activities for its graduates. Systems that are responsive to 
labor market needs and opportunities have to be created  to ensure that relevant occupational 
areas are identified, and related skills and training standards, as well as training programs, are 
developed and updated. The private sector and commerce and industry employers should be 
more actively involved in, and labor market information should help guide the development or 
update of, training programs. Current skills and training standards and their related curricula 
need to be reviewed vis-à-vis market demands, and updated as necessary. Some training 
programs will need to be revised to keep up with the latest technologies.  
 
6.  The quality of formal training programs needs to improve. Pass rates for the SSC(Voc) 
examination averaged 45% from 2003 and 2004. In 2002, only 19% of HSC(Voc) examinees 
passed. TVET teachers and trainers need to upgrade their skills and knowledge, as many are 
untrained and lack practical experience. The demand for trained trainers and teachers cannot 
be filled by the present system—only one vocational teachers’ training institution and one 
technical teachers’ training institution produce a combined total of about 300 graduates annually. 
In  addition,  training  equipment  should  be  upgraded  to  meet  market  needs  and  training 
standards.   
 
7.  Access to skills training under the present TVET system is limited and geared primarily 
toward male students who have completed grade 8. Each year, more than 600,000 children 
leave primary education and over 600,000 secondary education students leave school before 
grade 9. Many of those who leave school come from poor households and lack skills necessary 
for jobs or income-generating activities (Appendix 2). Semiskilled and skilled workers who need 
not have completed secondary education are in demand, but few training programs meet this 
need. Lessons can be learned from the experiences of public training institutions, NGOs, and 
private training providers offering short-term training that is responsive to market needs and 
does not require completion of grade 8. Training programs can be flexible in duration, schedule, 
and age and education requirements. Although almost half of those who leave school are 
females, they comprise only about a quarter of TVET students. More females need to be 
attracted to TVET, including nontraditional trades for females, to improve their job opportunities 
and income.  
 
8.  The Government provides assistance to over 600 nongovernment training providers, as 
well as stipends to some trainees. The Government provides assistance to TVET to aid the 
country’s  economic  development  and  give  equal  access  to  training  to  a  broad  range  of 
stakeholders. Improving the relevance and quality of, and access to, TVET will require more 
resources. Unit costs in TVET are generally higher than in general education. More funds are 
needed to (i) operate, maintain, and optimally use training equipment; (ii) provide adequate 
consumable training supplies and materials; and (iii) provide in-service training to trainers and 
teachers. A strategy should be developed to ensure that training programs receive adequate 
resources, run efficiently, and are conducted in a sustainable manner. Lessons can be learned 
from successful activities of private institutions and NGOs. The administration and management

of  government  training  institutions  need  to  be  reviewed  and  strengthened  for  better 
management, improved entrepreneurial skills, and greater flexibility.  
 
9.  ADB’s country strategy for Bangladesh supports the PRS and continues assistance for 
social development. ADB provides assistance to primary and secondary education.6 Its key 
priority in developing the country’s skills base includes improving the quality and relevance of 
TVET.  One  of  the  lessons  identified  from  ADB  assistance  in  education  and  training  in 
Bangladesh and other countries is that training programs must be linked to labor market needs. 
ADB will help the TVET system achieve greater flexibility and be responsive to labor market 
needs and requirements of the informal sector. ADB will coordinate with development partners 
that are interested in engaging in the TVET subsector, particularly the World Bank and the 
European Union. The World Bank is interested in assisting TVET and has initiated a sector 
study.  The  European  Union  is  interested  in  providing  capacity-strengthening  technical 
assistance and piloting some training activities.  
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The objective of the project preparatory TA is to help the Government prepare a project 
proposal for possible project loan financing to improve the relevance, quality, access, efficiency, 
and financing of TVET. This will contribute to improving the country’s skills base, provide more 
people with income-generating opportunities, and help reduce poverty. The TA will have the 
following outputs: (i) situation analysis; (ii) recommendations for necessary TVET policy reforms 
and development activities; and (iii) project loan design proposal, which includes support for the 
development  of  short-term  training  programs  and  basic  skills  development,  capacity 
strengthening, and project implementation.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
11.  The TA will conduct a situation analysis of the TVET subsector. The analysis will build 
on TVET assessments and studies undertaken by the World Bank, other development partners, 
research organizations, and NGOs. The TA will examine TVET-related policies, including (i) 
interministerial  coordination  and  scope  and  distribution  of  responsibilities,  (ii)  labor  market 
regulations,  (iii)  training  incentives  for  employers,  (iv)  training  and  labor  policies,  and  (v) 
regulatory framework of nongovernment training providers, including those operating for profit. 
After the analysis is completed, the TA will recommend potential TVET policy reform and 
development activities to improve relevance, quality, access, efficiency, and financing. The TA 
will then develop a project design aimed at the same subsector objectives, to be proposed for 
possible project loan financing by ADB. The project design proposal may include (i) developing 
linkages and partnerships with the private sector and employers; (ii) strengthening the capacity 
of  TVET  administration  and  training  and  teaching  personnel;  (iii) development  of  TVET 
administration systems; (iv) development of skills and training standards and training curricula, 
including for short-term training and madrasahs; (v) development of qualifications framework

and  accreditation  systems,  as  appropriate;  (vi) development  of  training  materials; 
(vii) undertaking civil works, as appropriate; (viii) upgrading training equipment; (ix) support for 
improving the quality of training offered by nongovernment providers; (x) increasing women’s

implementation plan and recommended policy adjustments to sustain project effectiveness. The 
proposal will take into consideration assistance to be given by the EU, the World Bank, and 
other development partners.  
 
12.  The TA will conduct a labor market study to identify occupational areas where the supply 
of trained workers does not meet the demand. The study will help identify training programs—
including programs offering more training to women and to those who leave school before grade 
9—that will be strengthened or developed by the project. The TA will also (i) examine the 
market relevance and opportunities for women and early school leavers of the TVET curricula 
and training programs currently delivered by government schools and institutions, including 
madrasahs;  (ii)  conduct  a  study  of  the  capacity  strengthening  needs  of  selected  training 
institutions that could be supported through the proposed project; (iii) make recommendations 
on necessary institutional strengthening inputs; and (iv) review the different mechanisms for 
delivering TVET, including modular courses and make recommendations for alternative training 
program delivery.  
 
13.  The TA will conduct stakeholder workshops and focus group discussions to (i) support 
the  situation  analysis,  (ii)  solicit  inputs  and  feedback  on  TVET  reform  and  investment 
recommendations, and (iii) refine the project design proposal. Stakeholders will include school-
leavers,  representatives  of  relevant  government  agencies,  and  representatives  of  private 
training providers and NGOs. TA implementation will ensure that employer representatives are 
actively involved in consultations and discussions. The TA will coordinate with development 
partners that are engaged or planning to engage in the TVET subsector. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $625,000. ADB will finance the 
equivalent of $500,000. The remaining $125,000 will be contributed by the Government and will 
include  office  accommodation,  utilities,  transport,  remuneration  of  counterpart  staff,  and 
administration support. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the Japan Special 
Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government has been informed that approval 
of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MOE will be the Executing Agency for the TA. A project steering committee (PSC) will be 
established to provide overall guidance to the TA team. The PSC, chaired by the secretary of 
MOE, will comprise (i) representatives from the ministries of Expatriate Welfare and Overseas 
Employment,  Labour  and  Employment,  Youth  and  Sports,  Women  and  Children’s  Affairs, 
Industries,  and  Commerce;  (ii)  representatives  of  the  Economic  Relations  Division;  
the  Planning  Commission;  Department  of  Technical  Education;  Bureau  of  Manpower, 
Employment  and  Training;  Bangladesh  Technical  Education  Board;  and  the  Bangladesh 
Madrasah Education Board; (iii) at least three members representing industry, employers, and 
private training providers; and (iv) an NGO representative. At least two members will be women. 
The PSC will be established before the start of the TA. It will meet at least once in the early 
phase of implementation to discuss the situation analysis, and at least twice in the later phase to

5
provide guidance on policy reforms and proposed investment activities. The PSC will (i) monitor 
the progress of the TA; (ii) provide policy and project guidance; (iii) establish ownership by the 
Government; (iv) ensure and facilitate coordination across different stakeholders; (v) ensure that 
the design maximizes the development impact for the poor; and (vi) support the ensuing loan 
processing, if any.  
 
16.  The  Government  will  appoint  a  focal  person  to  work  directly  with  the  TA  team.  
The focal person will also attend PSC meetings. MOE and the Ministry of Expatriate Welfare 
and Overseas Employment will designate counterpart staff to work on a part-time basis with the 
consultants. MOE will provide administrative support and adequate office space. The office will 
have utilities, furniture, local telephone services, and internet access. The consulting firm will 
procure  equipment,  software,  and  furniture,  as  necessary,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines.  The  equipment,  software,  and  furniture  will  be  transferred  to  the 
Government on completion of the TA.  
 
17.  The TA will employ the services of three international (12.5 person-months) and five 
domestic (18.5 person-months) consultants for a total of 31 person-months. The international 
consultants will be specialists in (i) TVET policy, management, and institutional development; 
(ii) TVET programs; and (iii) TVET finance and economics. The domestic consultants will be 
specialists in (i) TVET policy, management, and institutional development; (ii) TVET programs; 
(iii)  TVET  teacher  and  trainer  training;  (iv) TVET  finance  and  economics;  and  
(v) gender and social development. The consultants will be engaged by ADB through a firm 
using the quality and cost-based selection method in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use 
of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  selection  of  domestic 
consultants. The simplified technical proposal will be used. Outline terms of reference are in 
Appendix 4.   
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 6 months, commencing in July 2006, and 
will be completed in December 2006. The TA team will submit (i) an inception report within 1 
month of TA commencement, (ii) a preliminary report of the situation analysis and initial policy 
matrix  within  2  months,  (iii)  a  preliminary  design  and  monitoring  framework  within  
3 months; (iv) the draft final report within 4 months, and (v) the final report within 6 months.  
The TA will include field visits, stakeholder mapping, and institutional mapping; and undertake 
consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, including parents, teachers, and administration 
officials at various levels. The consultants will organize regional and national workshops and 
focus group discussions to solicit and discuss views and recommendations, and discuss options 
and activities.  
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Bangladesh  for  preparing  the  Skills  Development  Project,  and  hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh: 
Access to skills training under the present technical and vocational education training (TVET) system is limited. Each 
year, more than 600,000 primary school-leavers and over 600,000 secondary students leaving before grade 9—many 
of whom come from poor households—lack skills for employment or income generation. Semiskilled and skilled 
workers who need not have completed secondary education are in demand, but few training programs address this. 
 
The Government’s National Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper prioritizes TVET and making education more job-
oriented to accelerate poverty reduction. Government policy aims to (i) substantially increase the proportion of post-
primary students enrolling in TVET; and (ii) expand it for the poor, youth, and women. TVET will focus on market-
driven skill formation.   
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
The poverty analysis will examine the income profile of school-leavers and students potentially interested in TVET. 
It will analyze poverty-related factors that affect TVET enrollment, retention, and completion. This will include 
identifying factors that constrain potential trainees from joining TVET, and the poor’s perception of TVET’s role in 
improving their economic status. The profile of economic activities in which the poor are or could engage will be 
examined in relation to available TVET programs. The analysis will employ statistical data and qualitative information. 
Statistical data will be from surveys conducted by the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics and the Bangladesh Bureau of 
Educational Information and Statistics. Qualitative information will be from published and unpublished studies and 
focus group discussions to be conducted by the project preparatory technical assistance (TA). The situation analysis 
will include (i) descriptions of the characteristics of the poor, (ii) identification of districts and/or communities with high 
numbers of poor residents, and (iii) capacity of TVET providers. The analysis will examine and recommend strategies 
to involve the poor and employers in their communities to improve the relevance and quality of TVET. 
   
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
The TA will undertake stakeholder analysis and institutional mapping as part of the situation analysis.    
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
The TA will engage a gender and social development specialist to analyze the factors influencing the participation of 
school-leavers, women, and minorities in TVET. The specialist will make recommendations on financially sustainable 
ways to encourage school-leavers, women, and minorities to undertake TVET. The specialist will undertake focus 
group discussions and use participatory methodologies.     
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
The gender and social development specialist will analyze factors influencing women’s participation in TVET. The 
analysis will include a description and analysis of women’s education and employment situation, including constraints 
on TVET participation and job searches. The specialist will review the experiences of training programs that were 
successful in attracting women, and identify vocational training areas that are or may be potentially attractive to 
women.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
A.   International Consultants 
 
1.  Technical  and  Vocational  Education  and  Training  (TVET)  Policy, 
Management,  and  Institutional  Development  Specialist—Team  Leader  
(5 person-months).  
 
1.  As  team  leader,  the  consultant  will  have  experience  in  leading  a  TVET  project 
preparation activity and awareness of Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) project preparation 
requirements. The team leader will provide advice to and coordinate with the Government and 
lead the project preparatory technical assistance (TA) team in developing the proposed project 
design and monitoring framework. The consultant will be responsible for the collective work of 
the TA team, including the preparation and timely submission of reports, appendices, and 
studies; conduct of surveys, stakeholder consultations, and workshops; and preparation of 
safeguards compliance documentation as necessary. The consultant will be a good project 
proposal writer. The consultant will lead the coordination with relevant government agencies, 
employers, nongovernment organizations, development partners, and ADB. The consultant will 
coordinate TVET analyses and activities with development partners, particularly the European 
Union and the World Bank. 
  
2.  As specialist, the consultant will have expertise and extensive experience in the TVET 
subsector,  including  the  analysis,  development,  and  implementation  of  TVET  policies;  and 
management of TVET systems and institutions. The consultant will undertake a TVET situation 
analysis,  identifying  and  examining  issues  and  policies  affecting  TVET  quality,  relevance, 
access,  efficiency,  and  financing.  The  consultant  will  build  on  TVET  sector  work  already 
undertaken by the World Bank, other development partners, and TVET stakeholders. In close 
consultation with stakeholders, the specialist will develop a development plan, including relevant 
policy recommendations and investment activities. The specialist will also assess the TVET 
teacher training system. Specifically, the specialist will: 
 
(i)  assess the overall TVET policy, institutional, and investment framework; and 
survey government investment and labor policies, regulations, and strategies that 
impact  on  training  (including  training  incentives  given  to  employers  and 
regulation of nongovernment, including private, training institutions); 
(ii)  perform an institutional stakeholder mapping and analysis (including madrasahs, 
nongovernment  training  providers  and  nongovernment  organizations,  and 
development partners); and review the roles, mandates, and ongoing activities of 
government TVET stakeholders (including central agencies, training providers, 
and madrasahs); 
(iii)  review the role of nongovernment organizations as training providers and derive 
lessons from their experiences; review the role of the private sector as training 
provider, financier, and end user of TVET; develop recommendations to facilitate 
and encourage their participation in TVET in all these roles; 
(iv)  develop mechanisms for a coordinated TVET subsector to improve efficiency, 
relevance, quality, and access. Possible options could include establishing a 
central training authority and streamlining institutional mandates and activities; 
(v)  assess  management  and  administration  practices  and  capacities  (including 
managerial and entrepreneurial skills) in government TVET agencies and training 
institutions to improve their relevance, quality, and efficiency; recommend ways

B.   National Consultants 
 
5.  The national consultants will work closely with their international counterparts to obtain 
the knowledge and information necessary to analyze the needs of the subsector, and develop 
policy and investment activity options. The consultants will provide background information and 
advice to help the international consultants understand the status of issues related to performing 
their tasks. The consultants will assist Ministry of Education (MOE) and international consultants 
in conducting workshops and face-to-face interviews. The consultants will work closely with the 
international consultants and liaise with the MOE and other government agencies in planning 
meetings, arranging appointments, and obtaining data and information. The consultants will 
perform other tasks as may be reasonably assigned by ADB. 
 
1.    TVET  Policy,  Management,  and  Institutional  Development  Specialist—
Deputy Team Leader (5.5 person-months)  
 
6.  The  consultant  will  have  experience  and  knowledge  of  the  TVET  subsector  in 
Bangladesh. The consultant will be a good project proposal writer. The consultant will act as the 
deputy  team  leader.  The  consultant  will  contribute  to  analyzing  the  TVET  situation.  
The  consultant  will  work  with  the  international  consultant  to  develop  TVET  policy 
recommendations,  a  TVET  subsector  development  plan,  project  design  and  monitoring 
framework, and TVET investment activities.  
 
2.   TVET Programs Specialist (5.5 person-months)  
 
7.  The consultant will have experience and knowledge of government and nongovernment 
TVET programs, including short-term, and TVET institutions in Bangladesh. The consultant will

work with the international consultant in analyzing the quality, relevance, and efficiency of TVET 
programs  and  institutions.  The  consultant  will  help  identify  TVET  institutions  and  training 
programs that could be assisted through the project. The consultant will research short-term 
programs and nongovernment long-term programs from which lessons could be identified.

8.  The consultant will have experience and knowledge of the teacher and trainer training

4.   TVET Finance and Economics Specialist (3 person-months)  
 
9.  The consultant will have experience in costing education projects, well-versed in the use 
of EXCEL. The consultant will be knowledgeable of the various existing economic, education, 
and household data sets that can be used in undertaking a socioeconomic analysis for the 
proposed  project.  The  consultant  should  have  basic  understanding  of  conducting  surveys.  
The consultant will assist the international TVET finance and economics specialist in collecting

5.   Gender and Social Development Specialist (2.5 person-months)  
 
10.  The consultant will have experience in analyzing the situation of women, the poor, and 
ethnic minorities. The consultant will be experienced in employing participatory methodologies 
to collect and analyze information, and developing relevant action plans. The consultant should 
have a good understanding of relevant ADB policies. The consultant will conduct a situation 
analysis of the poor, including the income profile of school-leavers and TVET students and 
trainees. The consultant will analyze the employment and livelihood and training situation of 
women, the poor, and ethnic minorities, including each group’s income profile and engagement 
in training programs. The consultant will compile and analyze the economic activities in which 
women, the poor, and ethnic minorities are or could engage; examine factors affecting the 
decision of women, the poor, and ethnic minorities to enroll in and complete TVET programs; 
and identify vocational training areas that are or may be potentially attractive to women, which 
are in demand in the labor market. The consultant will review the experiences of the more 
successful  training  programs  in  attracting  women,  the  poor,  and  ethnic  minorities,  and 
recommend  appropriate  activities  and  procedures  to  be  included  in  the  proposed  project.  
The consultant will explore and assess the perception of TVET by women, the poor, and ethnic 
minorities in relation to their economic and social advancement. The consultant will develop a 
gender action plan, an ethnic minority development framework and plan, and an involuntary 
resettlement framework and plan. The consultant will develop recommendations of appropriate 
TVET  activities  and  procedures  for  the  proposed  project  to  encourage  the  participation  of 
women, the poor, and ethnic minorities in market-responsive TVET programs. The consultant 
will assess the criteria for giving stipends, in terms of equity and efficiency considerations, and 
recommend refinements as appropriate. The consultant will be responsible for the Summary 
Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy appendix and perform other tasks as may be reasonably 
assigned by ADB.
